importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 17, 2025, to address the current surge in electricity costs linked to AI development and data center expansion.
The average price of electricity in the U.S. has increased 13% since 2022, highlighting a long-term trend that has been accelerating due to AI-related demand.
Electricity consumption by data centers rose from 4.4% of U.S. usage in 2023 to 6.7%–12% by 2028, signaling a significant shift in energy consumption patterns.
A December 2024 Department of Energy report projected future data center electricity consumption, indicating a clear trajectory of increased demand driven by AI.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: From 2023 to 2028, data center electricity consumption is projected to rise from 4.4% to 6.7%–12% of U.S. usage, marking a dramatic increase in energy demand.

keyTakeAways: Electricity bills are rising due to increased demand from AI-powered data centers, especially as tech companies invest heavily in AI infrastructure.
The U.S. energy grid is struggling to keep up with rising electricity demand from AI-driven technologies, leading to higher retail prices.
Data centers are projected to consume 6.7% to 12% of U.S. electricity by 2028, up from 4.4% in 2023, according to the Department of Energy.
AI tools are becoming more computationally intensive, requiring more power and contributing to the surge in electricity demand.
Some states, like Oregon, have passed legislation requiring data centers to pay for their grid impact, so consumers aren’t burdened with those costs.
Existing pricing models in the electricity market don’t fully account for the massive growth in data center usage, creating a disconnect between consumer bills and actual energy strain.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her personal experience illustrates a real-world example of rising electricity costs that many consumers are now facing, sparking public concern and discussion.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Electricity bills are rising across the U.S. due to a surge in demand driven by artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure. Consumers like Lindsey Martin in Kentucky are seeing dramatic bill increases—from around $150 to over $370—mirroring a national trend. Experts point to the massive investments by tech giants such as OpenAI, Broadcom, Meta, and Microsoft in AI-powered data centers, which are consuming more electricity than ever. Data center electricity use is projected to rise from 4.4% of U.S. usage in 2023 to 6.7%–12% by 2028. This demand is outpacing the power grid’s ability to adapt, and current pricing models do not account for the strain caused by AI, leading to higher retail electricity costs. Some states, like Oregon, are attempting to address this by requiring data centers to pay directly for grid impact. The article underscores a critical energy challenge: the AI boom is fundamentally reshaping electricity consumption and pricing, raising urgent questions about infrastructure investment, equity, and sustainability.
title: Is AI really making electricity bills higher? Here’s what the experts say
